newsitem.title: TOGO: West African states back Congo peace force.
newsitem.headline: West African states back Congo peace force.

text.p: Eight West African states pledged at a summit meeting in Lome on Monday to back an international peacekeeping force for Congo, and Togo and Senegal said they would provide troops.

In a declaration, the heads of state and government said their countries would be "available to take part in this peace force under the authority of the UN and the OAU (the Organisation of African Unity)".

Officials from the eight countries of the West African Economic and Monetary Union (UEMOA) -- Togo, Benin, Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Guinea-Bissau and Senegal -- said the mission could be put together rapidly.

Supporters of President Pascal Lissouba and his predecessor, Denis Sassou Nguesso, have been fighting each other in Brazzaville since June 5. A truce was called on June 17, but heavy shelling and gunfire was reported on Monday.
UMEOA saluted "the humanitarian action undertaken by France to save human lives" in Congo.
France evacuated almost 6,000 foreign nationals from Congo but declined to leave its soldiers in the capital to act as a buffer force between the warring sides.

The UEMOA leaders also called for a peaceful resolution to the fighting in Bangui, the capital of Central African Republic, where disaffected soldiers have clashed with members of an African peacekeeping force sent in after previous mutinies, and with French troops stationed there under a defence agreement.
In a statement, the heads of state said they "deplored the fresh outbreak of fighting in Central African Republic and in particular the attack against MISAB (the African peace-keeping mission)".
They also called for a return to "constitutional order" in Sierra Leone, which remains tense after a military coup on May 25.

The leaders found time to discuss economic matters, including further moves towards constructing a free trade area in the sub-region, and the setting-up of a regional bourse, to be situated in Abidjan, the commercial capital of Ivory Coast.
Officials said the project had been delayed by problems to do with computer systems, but they said it would be up and running towards the end of 1997.
